citeinfo.origin: Miller, Mark, Jayne Belnap, Susan Beatty, and Bruce Webb
citeinfo.title: Components of Spatial and Temporal Soil Variation at Canyonlands National Park: Implications for P Dynamics and Cheatgrass (Bromus tectorum) Performance
citeinfo.othercit: Science Information System Project #: 762 Publication Control #: 1044

descript.abstract: Distinct soil-vegetation patterns are remarkably apparent in arid and semiarid landscapes. Patterns of vegetation have been correlated with geomorphic variables such as parent material, profile development, and topography. However, identifying the mechanisms underlying these plant-soil relationships is more challenging. A U.S. Geological Survey ecologist, Jayne Belnap, has teamed up with an ecologist at the Bureau of Land Management, a geographer at the University of Colorado, and a soil scientist at Brigham Young University, in an effort to understand the complex nature of plant-soil interactions. A clear understanding of plant-soil patterns is particularly important when considering the applied problem of invasive exotic species. In this particular study, researchers focused on how cheatgrass, an invasive species in the Western United States, behaved over time and space when soil variables were altered.
